channel.title: IntentionallyEmpty on Jeff's Resume
channel.description: Recent content in IntentionallyEmpty on Jeff's Resume

item.title: Kustomize
item.description: The two problems here were Managing the dozens or possibly thousands of variants of the desired state of a cluster or set of clusters. Leading an open source project from nothing to 6500 github stars and over 100 contributors. To create a kubernetes cluster, one declares the state of all cluster objects in files, then applies those files to the cluster. To edit the cluster one edits these files and reapplies them.

item.title: Education
item.description: Ph.D. Physics, University of California, San Diego Electron Transfer in Proteins: The Electron Tunneling Matrix. TA for Sally Ride. M.S. Elect. Engineering, University of Iowa, Iowa City Optical Switching at a Nonlinear Dielectric Interface. TA signal processing and control theory. Eta-Kappa-Nu EE Honor Society. B.S. Computer Science University of Iowa, Iowa City

item.title: Awards
item.description: Spot Bonus Helpouts launch G+ games launch Conops Engineer Appreciation: iGoogle Executive Mgmt Group Impact Award: iGoogle OC Award: Custom Search Engine launch

item.title: Terrabella
item.description: Worked on problems in satellite management Conversion of optimization solutions for communication and image capture to satellite commands. Conversion of orbitology software (TLE to orbital states computation) to Google systems. Development cycle for the above, including deployment, rollbacks, and requirements collection from the flight teams. Worked for one year on this, before sale of Terrabella to Planet.

item.title: Vanadium
item.description: Problem: How can distributed servers find each other, securely communicate, and delegate authority. This project was a predecessor to kubernetes and Google fuchsia. It required building libraries for service construction and discovery, a grpc-like service and protobuffer language, and a wonderful model of delegatable authorization based on public-key cryptography. I contributed to the libraries and overall project organization, wrote extensive, tested tutorials, and built demos for android, ios and X11.

item.title: Helpouts
item.description: Problem: How can Google literally connect a query to an expert? Google helpouts was Google’s attempt to turn video chat into a business platform. If a Google query for How to fix a toilet leak? failed, it could connect you to an actual human plumber who’d talk to you and walk you through the repair on a paid tutorial platform. I worked on the android app, the internal stack serving its API, integration with Google search, and the referral system.

item.title: Skills
item.description: Proficient: Go, kubernetes (contributor), GKE, GRPC, C++ (circa 2010), java (circa 2015), javascript, bazel, linux, shell, git Learning: flutter, constraint problems

item.title: G+ Games
item.description: TLM of 5-10 swe/qa/interns, coordinating with extended team of dozens engaged in various aspects of G+ (stream, auth, privacy, and api). Built the most complex part of the G+ web client, as allowed 3rd parts apps to run on google.com with appropriate risk mitigation. Launched first aspect of the G+ API to developers, preceeding what came second (activity stream listing) by over a year. launched first Oauth2 app on Google.

item.title: Projects
item.description: mdrip; extracts and runs fenced code blocks from markdown. A means to do literate programming with markdown and any language, to write testing tutorials. gorepomod; helps one deploy multiple Go modules from one respository when the modules have interdependencies. gol_grid; my from scratch implementation of Conway’s game of life using flutter. Flutter is amazing.

item.title: iGoogle
item.description: Google’s first attempt at both accepting POSTs (an external developer API) and social sharing. hmm1 hmm3 igoogle-blog igoogle-api gadget-authoring social sharing hmm3

item.title: Missle Defense UX
item.description: Managed team that built two cornerstone apps for the Reagan Test Site. The first gathered sensor (radar, optical, etc.) data from the network and presented it in ~30 different widgets (e.g., a radar bore-site view of incoming objects). The second app was a simulator to drive the displays for training. Set up iterative test and release cycles new to Lincoln. New tested versions of the apps are deployed every two weeks to the Reagan Test Site in Kwajalein, rather than once or twice a year at unpredictable times.

item.title: Eidogen
item.description: Second employee at Eidogen, a protein structure prediction startup. Led the team that built eve, which still seems to be available.
